results.title: A Bill of divorcement
results.creator_credit: RKO Radio Pictures, David O. Selznick and George Cukor
results.brief_description: Katharine Hepburn’s debut in what was to be the first film in a long association with director George Cukor. Hillary Fairfield, shellshocked during World War One, escapes from the asylum on the day his ex-wife is to remarry. Unable to adjust, he must also confront his now grown-up daughter Sydney. Facing reality, he finally accepts his wife’s determination to marry a sane, healthy man, but does not know of the impending sacrifice his daughter is to make. Sydney knows that the streak of madness in her father is inherited, not war-induced and, fearful of passing it on to her children, she cancels her marriage in order to care for her father.

results.title: A Big hand for everyone
results.creator_credit: Australian Broadcasting Commission and Michel Pearce
results.brief_description: The average man, in ignorance and confusion, has an optimistic view of his future. The expert, wrapped in his knowledge and expertise, is pessimistic. It is this disparity of belief that the political cartoonist and humorist, Bruce Petty, animates in his film. Petty sees the world and its problems as complex. He shows Man as a lonely figure on a unicycle, pedalling hard towards disaster. Awards: Golden Reel Award, AFI Awards 1971.

results.title: A Big country
results.creator_credit: Artransa Park Studios and Roland Litchfield
results.brief_description: Throughout Australia aluminium is being used more and more in a multitude of industries and particularly in transport. Across vast tracts of country aluminium road transports, buses, railway carriages, and aeroplanes fly daily. Fishing boats and pleasure craft, caravans and land are all now produced in aluminium. Tip trucks, plank floor trays and wheat hoppers, as well as domestic items such as foil have all been affected by the “aluminium revolution”.

results.title: A Better way
results.brief_description: In order to keep Canada’s vast quantities of mail moving, Canada Post dug around for a suitable solution. They came up with MAPP (Major Area Postal Plant), an ingenious, highly complex, streamlined system that relies on the postal code for efficient operation. The postal code relies on you and me, the mailing public, for inclusion in the address. The film tells what happens when a piece of mail is set on its course. No other credits available.

results.title: A Better train of thought
results.creator_credit: MAFILM Pannonia Filmstudio, Stephen Bosustow and Attila Dargay
results.brief_description: An animated allegorical comment on progress and power. Indignant when another train passes them, passengers on an old train try a variety of ways to speed it up - to no avail. They reject a revolutionary design proposed by one passenger, who leaves to return as the designer of an obviously superior vehicle.

results.title: A Better Tomorrow = Yingxiong Bense
results.creator_credit: Atlas Internation and Cinema City Co, Tsui Hark and John Woo
results.brief_description: Ho (Ti Lung), a gangster has a troubled relationship with his brother Kit (Leslie Cheung), a rookie cop. When Ho and Kit’s father is killed in a double-cross, Ho calls on his friend Mark (Chow Yun-fat) to avenge his death. The hit goes wrong and Mark is wounded and Ho is arrested. Three years later, Ho is released only to find his brother has turned against him and Mark, now crippled, is doing menial jobs for Shing (Lee Tse Ho), an up-and-coming crime boss. Ho’s attempt to stay on the straight and narrow is thwarted by Shing who goes after Kit and Mark. The brothers are forced to reconcile and Mark must make take one more hit job to save their lives. John Woo, who started his career in the sword-fighting martial art genre, recycles in a modern setting the concepts of honour among thieves, betrayal and vengeance that are at the core of most martial films. ‘A Better Tomorrow’ started the cycle of ‘Hero’ movies, with two subsequent spin-offs and many imitations. (The word ‘hero’ is culled from the film’s Chinese title, which, literally translated means ‘The Essence of Heroes’). The film places a renewed emphasis on male bonding and the homo-erotic aspect of violence with handsome and elegant gangsters engaging in choreographed gunfights. For critic Sek Kei the success of the Hong Kong Gangster film is a reflection of the changing values of a society in crisis. Faced with a potential breakdown of law and order in the years leading up to the 1997 handover, society and cinema reject the softness of love and romance to seek strength in macho bravado, true brotherhood and traditional anti-woman bias. Reference. Sek Kei ‘Achievement and crisis: Hong Kong cinema in the 80s’ The 15th Hong Kong Film festival catalogue (1991) See also: Stanley Kwan’s documentary on Chinese Cinema ‘Yang and yin: gender in Chinese cinema’ for an exploration of the homo-erotic subtext in Chinese movies. In Cantonese with English subtitles.

results.title: A Better man
results.brief_description: This film shows how, in Malaya, a modern prison is not a place of punishment, but a place of reconstruction. Reveals through the eyes of a newly convicted man under sentence of ten years imprisonment, exactly what lies before him and how the prison system of progress and privileges works. At the outset, it is explained to the prisoner what opportunities may be his, so that when he leaves prison he may be a more skilful, better educated man and a valuable citizen of Malaya. No other credits available.

results.title: A Better breed
results.brief_description: An account of the mechanism by which inherited characteristics are handed on from generation to generation, and an introduction to Mendel’s Laws of heredity. Gives examples of the inheritance of one or more characteristics; complete and incomplete dominance; and the recombinations of characteristics resulting in new types; refers to the practical aspects of this in connection with animal husbandry. No other credits available.

results.title: A Bell for Ursli
results.brief_description: This live action film takes place in the Canton of Grisons in Switzerland and illustrates an old custom; when spring comes the village boys chase away the winter with bells, rattles and cracking whips. Ursli, unhappy with his tiny bell, remembers a big bell in his father’s chalet high above the timber-line and sets off to get it.
